title: Advanced Pretexting and Business Email Compromise (BEC)
description: Sophisticated BEC attack targeting CFO using extensive OSINT, pretexting, and relationship building to execute fraudulent wire transfer. Demonstrates advanced social engineering tactics.
scenario: Red team assessment for manufacturing company to test financial controls and employee awareness. Goal: impersonate CEO and convince CFO to authorize wire transfer using social engineering only (no technical exploitation). Full authorization with company leadership.

steps.action: Comprehensive OSINT on CEO and CFO
steps.expected_result: Detailed profiles: CEO (travel schedule, communication style, interests), CFO (Harvard MBA, responds to alumni outreach, golf enthusiast, typical working hours 7AM-6PM)
steps.explanation: Deep target knowledge enables convincing impersonation

steps.expected_result: Identified wire transfer approval process, typical amounts, vendor relationships, CFO's approval authority ($500K without board approval)
steps.explanation: Understanding procedures helps craft believable pretext

steps.action: Establish rapport with CFO via Harvard alumni angle
steps.expected_result: Week 1: Initial LinkedIn connection (accepted), Week 2: Coffee meeting invitation (accepted), Week 3: Established friendly relationship
steps.explanation: Trust-building phase critical for advanced BEC

steps.expected_result: CEO traveling to Asia next week (confirmed via social media posts, out-of-office auto-reply, public speaking schedule)
steps.explanation: CEO being unavailable makes pretext more believable

steps.action: Send urgent wire transfer request from spoofed CEO email
steps.expected_result: Email sent during CEO's Asia trip: 'Confidential acquisition opportunity. Legal requires immediate $450K wire transfer. Details in attached NDA. Call my international number if questions: +XX-XXX-XXX-XXXX (attacker's number)'
steps.explanation: Timing, urgency, confidentiality, and CEO unavailability create pressure

steps.expected_result: CFO called to verify, attacker answered using voice cloning technology, provided believable acquisition story, reinforced urgency, CFO verbally confirmed wire transfer approval
steps.explanation: Voice verification adds critical legitimacy layer

steps.action: Provide wire instructions and monitor compliance
steps.expected_result: Sent wire instructions to test account (monitored but not actual theft), CFO initiated wire transfer ($450K to test account), transaction flagged by bank but CFO confirmed as legitimate, wire completed within 4 hours
steps.explanation: Successful BEC demonstrates complete control process bypass

steps.expected_result: Transfer intercepted before completion, CFO debriefed (shocked at deception), comprehensive report generated documenting attack timeline, psychological techniques, control failures

outcome: Successful BEC demonstration - CFO authorized $450K wire transfer based purely on social engineering. Attack succeeded due to: extensive OSINT enabling realistic pretext, relationship building establishing trust, perfect timing (CEO unavailable), voice cloning adding verification layer, exploiting human psychology (urgency, authority, confidentiality). Zero technical controls prevented attack. Implemented remediation: mandatory dual approval for wires >$100K, verbal verification using pre-established code words, wire transfer callback to known numbers only, executive impersonation awareness training, email authentication (DMARC reject), regular BEC simulations. Subsequent tests showed 100% detection rate.
learning_objectives: Use voice cloning for verification bypass
